com.projetloki.genesis

Class BackgroundLayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.projetloki.genesis.BackgroundLayer

  • public final class BackgroundLayer
extends Object
    A background image to paint on the background area. Includes properties that specify the position in the background area at which the image must be painted, whether the image must be repeated horizontally/vertically, whether the image must be resized.

    Background layers are immutable. All the methods setting a property, e.g. noRepeatX(), return a new background layer that is similar to this background layer with the new property set.

    Author:
    Clément Roux
    See Also:
    Properties.Builder.setBackground(BackgroundLayer...), http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#ltbg-layergt

    • Method Detail

      • of

        public static BackgroundLayer of(Image image)
        Returns a new background layer for the given background image. The image is painted as-is at the top-left corner of the area, and then repeated horizontally and vertically.

      • noRepeat

        public BackgroundLayer noRepeat()
        Sets the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. The image is placed once and not repeated in any direction.

        There are two methods that set the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the painting area. You could always call noRepeat() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fill() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 20x20 and the background position is (0, 0) → fill
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 30x30 and the background position is (-5, -5) → fill
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 10x10 and the background position is (5, 5) → no-repeat
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 20x20 and the background position is (-1, -1) → no-repeat

      • fill

        public BackgroundLayer fill()
        Sets the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat', and specifies that the image fills the background painting area. Makes CSS sprite optimization possible.

        There are two methods that set the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the painting area. You could always call noRepeat() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fill() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 20x20 and the background position is (0, 0) → fill
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 30x30 and the background position is (-5, -5) → fill
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 10x10 and the background position is (5, 5) → no-repeat
        • The painting area is 20x20, the image is 20x20 and the background position is (-1, -1) → no-repeat

      • space

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer space()
        Sets the background-repeat property to 'space'. The image is repeated as often as will fit within the background positioning area without being clipped and then the images are spaced out to fill the area. The first and last images touch the edges of the area.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • round

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer round()
        Sets the background-repeat property to 'round'. The image is repeated as often as will fit within the background positioning area. If it doesn't fit a whole number of times, it is rescaled so that it does.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • noRepeatX

        public BackgroundLayer noRepeatX()
        Sets the x-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. The image is placed once and not repeated horizontally.

        There are two methods that set the x-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the width of the painting area. You could always call noRepeatX() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fillX() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 20x? and the background position is (0, ?) → fill-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 30x? and the background position is (-5, ?) → fill-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 10x? and the background position is (5, ?) → no-repeat-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 20x? and the background position is (-1, ?) → no-repeat-x

      • fillX

        public BackgroundLayer fillX()
        Sets the x-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat', and specifies that the image fills the width of the background painting area. The image is placed once and not repeated horizontally.

        There are two methods that set the x-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the width of the painting area. You could always call noRepeatX() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fillX() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 20x? and the background position is (0, ?) → fill-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 30x? and the background position is (-5, ?) → fill-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 10x? and the background position is (5, ?) → no-repeat-x
        • The painting area is 20x?, the image is 20x? and the background position is (-1, ?) → no-repeat-x

      • spaceX

public BackgroundLayer spaceX()
        Sets the x-component of the background-repeat property to 'space'. The image is repeated horizontally as often as will fit within the background positioning area without being clipped and then the images are spaced out to fill the area. The first and last images touch the edges of the area.

      • noRepeatY

        public BackgroundLayer noRepeatY()
        Sets the y-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. The image is placed once and not repeated vertically.

        There are two methods that set the y-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the height of the painting area. You could always call noRepeatY() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fillY() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x20 and the background position is (?, 0) → fill-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x30 and the background position is (?, -5) → fill-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x10 and the background position is (?, 5) → no-repeat-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x20 and the background position is (?, -1) → no-repeat-y

      • fillY

        public BackgroundLayer fillY()
        Sets the y-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat', and specifies that the image fills the height of the background painting area. The image is placed once and not repeated vertically.

        There are two methods that set the y-component of the background-repeat property to 'no-repeat'. To know which one to call, you must determine whether the background image will fill the height of the painting area. You could always call noRepeatY() but then Genesis won't be able to create CSS sprites to reduce the number of images to download - there may be a performance penalty. But if you call fillY() when you are not supposed to, you may end up with bad surprises. See these examples:

        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x20 and the background position is (?, 0) → fill-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x30 and the background position is (?, -5) → fill-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x10 and the background position is (?, 5) → no-repeat-y
        • The painting area is ?x20, the image is ?x20 and the background position is (?, -1) → no-repeat-y

public BackgroundLayer spaceY()

      • position

        public BackgroundLayer position(String cssCode)
        Sets the background-position property, that is the position in the background area at which the image is painted.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given CSS code is not a valid background-position
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-position

      • positionPx

        public BackgroundLayer positionPx(int left,
                         int top)
        Sets the background-position property, in pixels. The background position is the position in the background area at which the image is painted.

      • positionPxPct

        public BackgroundLayer positionPxPct(int left,
                            double top)
        Sets the background-position proxy. The x-component is expressed in pixels and the y-component in percent of the background area's height.

      • positionPctPx

        public BackgroundLayer positionPctPx(double left,
                            int top)
        Sets the background-position property. The x-component is expressed in percent of the background area's width, and the y-component in pixels.

      • positionPct

        public BackgroundLayer positionPct(double left,
                          double top)
        Sets the background-position property. The x-component is expressed in percent of the background area's width, and the y-component in percent of the background area's height.

      • size

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer size(String cssCode)
        Sets the background-size property. The image will be resized before being painted on the background area..
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given CSS code is not a valid background-size
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-size, Browser support

      • sizePx

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer sizePx(int width,
                                        int height)
        Sets the background-size property. The new width and the new height are expressed in pixels.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • sizePxPct

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer sizePxPct(int width,
                                           double height)
        Sets the background-size property. The new width is expressed in pixels, and the new height in percent of the background area's height.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • sizePctPx

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer sizePctPx(double width,

        Sets the background-size property. The new width is expressed in percent of the background area's width, and the new height in pixels.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • sizePct

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer sizePct(double width,
                                         double height)
        Sets the background-size property. The new width is expressed in percent of the background area's width, and the new height in percent of the background area's height.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • fixed

        public BackgroundLayer fixed()
        Sets the background-attachment property to 'fixed'. The background is fixed with regard to the viewport. By default, the background is fixed with regard to the element itself and does not scroll with its contents.

      • local

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer local()
        Sets the background-attachment property to 'local'. The background is fixed with regard to the element's contents: if the element has a scrolling mechanism, the background scrolls with the element's contents. In this case, the background behind the element's border (if any) scrolls as well, even though the border itself does not scroll with the contents.
        See Also:
        Browser support

      • paddingBoxClip

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer paddingBoxClip()
        Sets the background-clip property to 'padding-box'. The background is painted within (clipped to) the border box.
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-clip, Browser support

      • contentBoxClip

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer contentBoxClip()
        Sets the background-clip property to 'content-box'. The background is painted within (clipped to) the content box.
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-clip, Browser support

      • borderBoxOrigin

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer borderBoxOrigin()
        Sets the background-origin property to 'border-box'. The background position is relative to the border box.
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-origin, Browser support

      • contentBoxOrigin

        @PoorBrowserSupport
public BackgroundLayer contentBoxOrigin()
        Sets the background-origin property to 'content-box'. The background position is relative to the content box.
        See Also:
        http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#background-origin, Browser support
